medium: Black earthenware with incised and burnished decor
title: Black Amphora with Double Handles
text: This type of black earthenware is known as Lifan after the area of Szechwan province where such jars have been found. The vessel's waisted profile, two low handles, and raised spiral motifs are rather distinctive features for Han period ceramics. The closest aesthetic parallels occur in much older ceramics of Neolithic cultures like Ma-chang (c. 3000-2000 b.c.) and Hsin-tian (c. 1500 b.c.). This unglazed, hand built black earthenware seems to have remained a regional variant that did not survive the Eastern Han period.
description: black ovoid amphora with 4 oval-shaped incised designs on body; 2 bowed strap handles; mouth has 2 points
